docs.lead_paragraph: When the Senate Finance Committee resumes debate Tuesday on its health care bill, a proposal for a government-run insurance plan - the so-called public option - will take center stage.

headline.main: Focus on 'Public Option' When Senate Health Care Debate Resumes

docs.abstract: When the Senate Finance Committee resumes its health care debate Tuesday, the focus will be on the "public option."
docs.snippet: When the Senate Finance Committee resumes its health care debate Tuesday, the focus will be on the "public option."

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans are trying to use a clip from President Obama's recent Sunday morning media blitz as proof that Democrats plan to raise taxes through a health care overhaul. In a Web video released Monday morning, the Republican National Committee included a piece of an interview on Sept. 20 in which the ABC's interviewer George Stephanopoulos cited a dictionary in asking Mr. Obama how requiring individuals to purchase health insurance - and fining them if they do not - would not by definition be a new tax. Within hours, the Democratic National Committee fired off a fact-check style e-mail message, countering nearly every statement in the 100-second spot. Read all about it on the Caucus blog.

headline.main: Republicans Try to Use Obama's Own Words Against Him on Taxes

docs.abstract: A Republican National Committee Web video tries to use President Obama's own words against him to prove that a Democratic health overhaul would raise taxes.
docs.snippet: A Republican National Committee Web video tries to use President Obama's own words against him to prove that a Democratic health overhaul would raise taxes.

docs.lead_paragraph: A data trend that did not get highlighted in last week's coverage of the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll provides a glimpse of eroding public support for universal health care. Because the various bills in Congress tend to assume that not every uninsured person in the land would necessarily get health coverage even under a new system, the question of "universal" coverage may be largely theoretical. But in our cousin blog, The Caucus, Marjorie Connelly runs the numbers.

headline.main: Public Support Declining for Idea of 'Universal' Health Insurance

docs.abstract: Public support for the idea of "universal" health care coverage is eroding, according to a piece of the recent New York Times/CBS News Poll that has not yet received much attention.
docs.snippet: Public support for the idea of "universal" health care coverage is eroding, according to a piece of the recent New York Times/CBS News Poll that has not yet received much attention.

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans are using a clip from President Obama's recent Sunday morning media blitz for a little lesson in the vocabulary of health care reform. And Democrats were quick to fire back.
docs.abstract: Republicans and Democrats feud over the possibility of taxes levied in various health care bills.
docs.snippet: Republicans and Democrats feud over the possibility of taxes levied in various health care bills.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday I'll be part of a panel at CAP discussing the long-run fiscal outlook and what to do about it. And I've been trying to figure out just how big the long-run problem is. Herewith some back-of-the-envelope thoughts.
docs.abstract: If we get real health care reform AND we get a sane political scene the long-term fiscal outlook is serious but not scary.
docs.snippet: If we get real health care reform AND we get a sane political scene the long-term fiscal outlook is serious but not scary.

docs.lead_paragraph: Public support for universal health insurance is declining, according the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. About half, 51 percent, say the federal government should guarantee health insurance for all Americans, down slightly from 55 percent in July and 64 percent in June.

headline.main: Poll: Support for Government Health Insurance Declines a Bit

docs.abstract: The latest Times/CBS News survey shows a decline in public backing of universal care, depending on whether higher taxes or a higher deficit are in play.
docs.snippet: The latest Times/CBS News survey shows a decline in public backing of universal care, depending on whether higher taxes or a higher deficit are in play.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline.main: Health Care Reform Is a Woman's Issue

docs.abstract: Last week Michelle Obama spoke on why health insurance reform is a women's issue. A lot of numbers support her case, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: Last week Michelle Obama spoke on why health insurance reform is a women's issue. A lot of numbers support her case, an economist writes.
